Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the school collected $5.4 million in taxpayer subsidies since first opening, when in reality it received about $1.1 million in the 2014-15 school year.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that the school collected $5.4 million in taxpayer subsidies since first opening.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the school closed immediately after receiving the $5.4 million in taxpayer subsidies, which is not accurate.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing a clear timeline of when the school received the subsidies and when it closed.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for why the school closed, such as financial trouble and canceled bus service, which are not mentioned in the claim.
